h1. 📌 Test Historical Data Consistency – Student

----

h2. 🔹 What Is This Section in My System?

*Test Historical Data Consistency* is a validation principle in my system that ensures *all historical data related to a request is preserved and displayed consistently, accurately, and reliably over time*.

This means:

* What the student saw yesterday is exactly what they will see today
* Historical data does not change retroactively
* There are no inconsistencies between statuses, dates, notes, and documents

h2. 🎯 Purpose of This Section

The main purposes of this section are to:

* Ensure full reliability of request data
* Prevent modification or deletion of existing history
* Maintain a clear and continuous record of the handling process
* Allow the student to trust the information displayed in the system

h2. 🧭 What Is Verified as Part of Test Historical Data Consistency?

This validation focuses on several key components:

h3. 1️⃣ Status Consistency

The system verifies that:

* Every status change is recorded
* The chronological order is correct
* There are no illogical transitions between statuses

📌 Examples:

* An “Approved” status cannot appear before “In Progress”
* A status cannot disappear from the history

h3. 2️⃣ Date and Time Consistency

The system verifies that:

* Every status has an associated date and time
* Dates and times match the order of actions
* The submission date never changes

📌 From the student’s perspective:

* The submission date remains constant
* Update timestamps remain exactly as recorded

h3. 3️⃣ Notes Consistency

The system verifies that:

* Notes added by the secretary or department head are not altered
* Notes cannot be deleted or edited retroactively
* Each note is linked to the correct status and timestamp

h3. 4️⃣ Documents Consistency

The system verifies that:

* Every uploaded document is preserved
* No documents disappear from the request history
* Each document is linked to the correct request and upload date

h3. 5️⃣ Consistency Across Different Screens

The system verifies that:

* The same information is displayed consistently across:
** The Student Dashboard
** The Request Details page
** The Secretary and Lecturer views

📌 The student, secretary, and lecturer all see *the same historical record* of the request.

h2. 🔒 What Can the Student _Not_ Do in This Context?

* ❌ Edit historical records
* ❌ Delete statuses
* ❌ Change dates or timestamps
* ❌ Modify past notes or documents

The request history is *final and immutable*.

h2. 🔁 Connection to the Overall System Flow

This principle integrates into the overall process as follows:

# The student submits a request
# Every action is recorded as historical data
# The secretary and lecturer update statuses and notes
# All updates are permanently stored
# The student views a consistent and reliable history

h2. 🧠 Why Is This an Important Part of My System?

Because it:

* Prevents disputes about “what happened and when”
* Builds trust between the student and the system
* Enables auditing and post-review
* Strengthens the academic and administrative credibility of the system

h2. 📝 Short and Clear Summary

*Test Historical Data Consistency* ensures that all historical request data—statuses, dates, notes, and documents—is stored in a consistent, accurate, and immutable manner.
This allows the student to track the request transparently and reliably throughout its entire lifecycle.

h1. 📌 Ensure Read-Only Access for Students – Student

h2. 🔹 What Is This Section in My System?

*Ensure Read-Only Access for Students* is a system principle that ensures that *after a request is submitted*, the student has *view-only access* to all request details.

This means:

* The student can *view* the information
* But *cannot modify* it

This principle is designed to maintain order, reliability, and control throughout the process.

h2. 🎯 Purpose of This Section

The main purposes of this section are to:

* Prevent data changes after submission
* Preserve data integrity
* Ensure a reliable and controlled handling process
* Create consistent documentation for all system stakeholders

h2. 🧭 When Does Read-Only Mode Apply?

h3. 🔸 Before Submitting the Request:

* All fields are editable
* The student can:
** Edit text fields
** Attach or remove documents
** Select request priority

h3. 🔸 After Submitting the Request:

* All fields are locked
* The request enters *Read-Only mode*

h2. 🖥️ How Is This Reflected on the Page?

After submission:

h3. 🔹 Text Fields

* Displayed as non-editable
* No text cursor is shown

h3. 🔹 Selection Lists (Dropdowns)

* Locked
* Displayed in read-only mode

h3. 🔹 Documents

* Available for viewing and downloading only
* Cannot be deleted or replaced

h3. 🔹 Action Buttons

* Edit buttons are removed or disabled
* Only view-related actions remain

h2. 🔒 What Can the Student _Not_ Do?

After submission, the student:

* ❌ Cannot edit request details
* ❌ Cannot change the priority
* ❌ Cannot add or remove documents
* ❌ Cannot change the request status

h2. 🔁 Connection to the Overall System Flow

This principle integrates into the overall process as follows:

# The student completes the request form
# The student submits the request
# My system locks the request for editing
# The secretary and lecturer process the request
# The student tracks the request in read-only mode

h2. 🧠 Why Is This an Important Part of My System?

Because it:

* Prevents uncontrolled data changes
* Ensures all parties view the same information
* Preserves the integrity of the approval process
* Avoids disputes or ambiguity

h2. 📝 Short and Clear Summary

*Ensure Read-Only Access for Students* guarantees that once a request is submitted, the student can only view the request details.
This protects data integrity, prevents unauthorized changes, and supports a structured and transparent request-handling process.

h2. 1️⃣ Purpose

The *Design Request Details Page* is the page where a student fills in, reviews, and submits an official request to the system.

This page serves as the *core submission point* where:

* All request information is collected
* Supporting documents are attached
* Request priority is defined
* The processing workflow with the *Secretary* and *Lecturer* is initiated

Once the request is submitted, *the student can no longer edit the request*.

h2. 2️⃣ Actor

*Primary Actor:*

* *Student* – initiates and submits the request

*Secondary Actors (not interacting directly on this page):*

* *Secretary*
* *Lecturer*

h2. 3️⃣ Entry Point

The student reaches the Design Request Details Page through the following steps:

# Logs into the system
# Enters the *Student Dashboard*
# Clicks *Submit New Request*
# Selects a request type
# Is automatically redirected to the *Design Request Details Page*

h2. 4️⃣ Page Layout and Components

h3. 🔹 Header

* Page title: *Request Details*
* Selected request type (read-only)
* Button to return to the Student Dashboard

h3. 🔹 Section 1: Student Information

This information is automatically loaded from the student account:

* Student Full Name
* Student Email
* Student ID

🔒 These fields are *read-only* and cannot be edited.

h3. 🔹 Section 2: Request Basic Details

*Fields include:*

* *Request Title* (Mandatory)
A short and clear title describing the request
* *Request Type*
Displayed based on the previous selection (read-only)
* *Related Course* (If applicable)
Selected from a list or via autocomplete

h3. 🔹 Section 3: Request Description

* *Detailed Description* (Mandatory)
A full explanation of the request, including:
** What the issue is
** Why the request is being submitted
** What the student is asking for
* *Reason / Justification*
The reason for submitting the request (e.g., medical, academic, personal)

h3. 🔹 Section 4: Priority Selection

The student selects the request priority:

* Low
* Medium
* High

ℹ️ *Note displayed on the page:*
Selecting a priority does not guarantee approval; it only helps manage the processing queue.

h3. 🔹 Section 5: File Attachments

The student can:

* Upload one or more files
* Upload allowed file types: *PDF / DOC / JPG / PNG*
* View a list of attached files
* Remove files before submission

📎 Attached documents are used by:

* The *Secretary* to verify completeness
* The *Lecturer* to support decision-making

h3. 🔹 Section 6: Validation Messages

The system performs the following validations:

* All mandatory fields are filled
* Uploaded files are valid
* File size limits are not exceeded

If an error occurs:

* An error message is displayed next to the relevant field
* The *Submit Request* button is disabled

h3. 🔹 Section 7: Action Buttons

Buttons displayed at the bottom of the page:

* *Submit Request* – submits the request
* *Cancel / Back* – returns to the previous page without saving

h2. 5️⃣ System Behavior After Submission (System Flow)

When the student clicks *Submit Request*:

# The request is saved in the database
# A unique *Request ID (REQ-XXX)* is generated
# The request status is set to *New*
# The request is forwarded to the *Secretary*
# The student is redirected back to the *Student Dashboard*
# The request appears in the *My Requests* list

h2. 6️⃣ What Happens Next (Outside the Page, Part of the Process)

h3. 🔹 Secretary Processing

* Receives the new request
* Verifies request details and attachments
* Classifies the request
* Forwards it to the relevant *Lecturer*

----

h3. 🔹 Lecturer Processing

* Reviews the request details and documents
* Makes a decision:
** *Approve*
** *Reject*

h3. 🔹 Return to Secretary

* The secretary updates the request status:
** *Approved* or *Rejected*

h3. 🔹 Student Notification

* The student sees the updated status on the dashboard
* There is *no direct communication* between student and lecturer

h2. 7️⃣ Business Rules

* A student cannot edit a request after submission
* A student can view only their own requests
* Request statuses can be updated only by the *Secretary* or *Lecturer*
* Priority selection does not guarantee approval
* All changes and actions are logged by the system

h2. 8️⃣ Scenarios

h3. ✔️ Success Scenario

The student completes all required fields, uploads supporting documents, and submits the request.
The request is successfully saved and appears on the Student Dashboard.

----

h3. ❌ Error Scenario

The student attempts to submit the request without completing a mandatory field.
The system blocks submission and displays a clear validation error message.
